I read up on viruses and there wasn't a hell of a lot known about them in 1940, which was when I was doing the research. I think it was about 40. Oh, it was earlier than that. Wait a minute. Well, I got the idea about the summer of 45 and was fooling around picking up information for the next three years or so. The first version of the story was finished in 48 and sent to John Campbell and he rejected it for a number of excellent reasons. And I did the 40,000 word two-part serial, sold it to him somewhere much later in 48 and it appeared first, I think, in April and May 49. But the research there was entirely biological and not very much was known about viruses in those days. So as we're in writing a sequel, as I'm supposed to be doing now, I'm having to do a lot of covering, but I'm damned if I'll tell you where. A contract initially said manuscript would be turned in September 1976. By September 1976, I had about 7,500 words done and spills started. I started over again in Christmas vacation and did about 8,500 more words, starting from scratch once more. Maybe I can use the first 7,500, but I've got a way to go yet. The contract has been extended to September 77 and I hope I don't have to strengthen for another extension. We might want their advance back instead. This would be bad. Well, this happens and some people can get away with it. I lack the drawl or self-confidence, whichever you want to call it, to feel sure that I'm one of them. I have told my wife if she wants to go to her sisters in the Bahamas for spring vacation, she may go and take our daughter with her. I'm not going. I'm staying home with the typewriter. Whether two and a half weeks spring vacation will really produce the rest of the book is a wide open question. But at least I keep getting more ideas and writing them down so maybe something can happen this spring. I hope so. I'd like to get it off my conscience so I can feel I can do something else. Yes. Never. When I've written the, they typed out the final draft. What I told myself firmly is the final draft. I can just barely bring myself to read it. There's some sort of acute postpartum depression there. And when it comes out as a book, I feel even worse. I know there are things I should have done otherwise. Take several years, usually before I can read the book of any sort of comfort. Yes. We've got a question here. Well, that's it. That's it. What time is it anyway? Okay.

segments.text: To science fiction lovers, if there are any mathematicians in the crowd who are purest
in the way the word infinity is used, I apologize in advance, but I warn you, if you get too
rough on me, I'll fight back.
My claim is that science fiction is an infinite activity, but there is no end to it.
It can go on forever and ever.
For our men, people can keep writing new stories, working out new ways of having fun with the
business, painting new pictures, I don't care how, making up more movies, plays, television
things, there is no limit.
This is my opinion for what it's worth.
I'm going to spend the rest of the yak in trying to defend it.
To do so, I'll have to stretch things perhaps a little bit.
I'll have to include in science fiction stuff that isn't pure, correct, hard, solid science
fiction such as I always write.
I'll have to let in occasional things which even have errors in them, horrid thought.
Like the notion that a planet which spins rapidly enough could have an elliptical cross-section
and have three G's at the equator and six hundred at the poles, you know.
Since it became easy to steal computer time, lots of people have checked up on me on that one
and apparently Mestlin would have come to a point at the edge.
Don't blame me.
I couldn't get hold of a computer in 1952.
So the errors will have to come in and they will ease very gradually over the edge into
what is frankly fantasy.
I don't really care where the line is drawn, but as long as we put this stuff all together,
I still think there's no end to it.
Now the mistakes cropped up even way back in the beginning in the days of Jude Fern when I was young.
And the first of the slides represents an interesting story which all of you have read,
but not this version of it.

but I could be a bit out.

all the types of amino acid, and the others were the mirror image, which produced an ecology which
Paul had a great deal of fun with. Okay.
This was almost on the side, and it's a painting of mine as well, and it represents an ambition I

it was partially fourth dimensional, and I want someday to paint a believable fourth dimensional
picture, but I just haven't succeeded yet. And I brought it in to mention that the fourth dimension
is used rather frequently, and has its own little infinity of story ideas, and I won't pursue that
one any further. There is a theme which has taken rather deep hold in the culture in the last 10
years or so, which also allows itself to be used in a variety of ways, especially playing the science
fiction game, capital letters. The game used to be that the author did his dam list to write a story
with no scientific errors in it, and after he had it published, the readers did the dam list to find
errors and write nasty letters to the editor's column. It is an unfair game. The author really is at
the short end of this stick. Once he's written and published the story, he's made all the moves he's
allowed, and everyone else can jump on him for the next 40 years of his bookstays in print,
God willing. There's a better way, and I will credit Gene Roddenberry for indirectly and not
deliberately, but as a result of his activities, teaching me that better way. Never mind shooting
down a Star Trek episode because it has a scientific error here and there. That is ethically
shooting a sitting bird. It is much better and much more of an intellectual exercise and much
more fun to take a Star Trek episode or a science fiction story, assume that it is accurate reporting
from soup to nuts, and then try to fill in the scientific background, the things that would
have to be true so that it could be accurate reporting. This is sometimes a job. The first
time I tackled it was the episode Dorothy Fontana's This Side of Paradise, which is a very nice,

which also were very efficient tranquilizers. And the only catch really, aside from the fact

on it. I think they'll ever have a really a passage. I think eventually yes, granting the
continuation of our technological culture, which we may or may not manage to keep up. I happen to
be in favor of it strongly. I like my little pocket calculators and the intellectual exercises they
make possible. I'm quoting almost directly from my article on atomic power in the current Galileo
at the moment. I like to get much more crude about it. I much prefer toilet paper made for the
purpose to any of the substitutes I've had to use on the farm and in camping during my lifetime.
From all of those various levels, I am very much in favor of a highly technical culture. I like books.
Yeah, we have it. And while I suppose I might survive in one in which our technology was gone,
and 95% of the population would have to spend 18 hours a day muscle-powered dirt farming,
I don't think I'd enjoy it. I have done muscle-powered dirt farming. My uncles in Canada were farmers.
I used to spend the summer with them. And frankly, pulling turnips is a useful and noble
action, but it's not for me.
Yep.
I don't know what I would have to sell a year to make a living because I don't make my living at it.
I'm a high school science teacher and science fiction writing and science fiction painting
are paying hobbies. I am not particularly embarrassed, but I don't know if the answer is
very useful. Last year, between painting and selling, but the selling included money from
books like Mission of Gravity published 25 years ago, I grossed about $6,500 to $7,000,
or on the order, well, rather less than half my teaching salary. So I'm not living on science fiction.
Probably. I can't speak for all of them. I think Paul Anderson makes his entire living by writing,
but not entirely science fiction. Isaac Dezimov, of course, makes his living by writing, but
well, he's a special case. He shows withdrawal symptoms if you get in too far from a typewriter.
And most of the other science fiction people I know do not make their living at it. It's
more of a paying hobby as it is with me. I don't know. He sold well enough in his heyday,
so I rather suspect that he did and probably still does. His books are constantly being reprinted.
I mean, I got a modest but not refusable check for about 160 bucks two days ago
for Italian reprint rights for Mission of Gravity. Who am I to sneer at this?
That's why I say the answer may not be all that useful to you. In the beginning, you're not getting
this sort of thing. It's the sort of stuff that accumulates after you've been writing for years.
And maybe eventually I'd be able to retire on it, but fortunately I won't have to depend on it
even then. I'll have those are pension, school, pension, and I don't know if that'll allow me
to collect social security with all that other money rolling in, but I thought I won't need it.
Yeah.
Where's the portion of your story? You start with the science fiction idea and then build the story
around it. That's my technique as a rule. Even with the hard science fiction based on some peculiar
planet, there are still two ways to go at it. My more usual one is to start with the odd ball
planet. I see an article in Sky and Telescope about a peculiar star and I read it up and then I
start figuring, well, how far out would a planet have to be from this star to have an average
earth temperature and what peculiarities would the star produce if it were that far out? How can
I complicate the issue by tilting the axis or making the orbit a little bit eccentric? I had a
great deal of fun with my H225 at that point. I'll have a lot more in the 97s.
And eventually I've got a very peculiar environment which all sorts of odd ball things can happen
and then I can write mission of gravity. The alternative, which I am not so good at doing,
but which is perfectly kosher for playing the game, is to decide what sort of environment you
want for your story. You may even have a pretty good idea of the story already and you know,
the environment it needs and then cook up a planet which could have that environment and
cook up a planetary system in which such a planet could exist. And I would be perfectly
willing to do this if I happen to have the pertinent idea. Not too many science fiction writers
happen to have the background which lets them do this. I'm not bragging and simply mentioning that
not too many writers besides myself major in astronomy as undergraduates.
On the other hand, we're a fairly friendly bunch. We swap information with each other.
Isaac used to call me up on a rather regular basis when he was doing that science column for
what was it? Magazine of Science and Fantasy, I guess, Science Fiction and Fantasy. And he'd
always be calling me up, but he lived near Boston then checking up on astronomical
bits. He's a biochemist. He doesn't know all that much astronomy. In fact, I must regretfully say
that I had just reviewed his book on Alpha Centauri and he made a gross slip, but I won't tell you
what it is. Did you do the sort of scientific preparation for heating? Yes, so what did you do?
Much less. I read up on viruses and there wasn't a hell of a lot known about them in 1940,
which was when I was doing the research. I think it was about 40. Oh, it was earlier than that.
Wait a minute. Well, I got the idea about the summer of 45 and was fooling around picking up
information for the next three years or so. The first version of the story was finished in 48
and sent to John Campbell and he rejected it for a number of excellent reasons. And I did the 40,000
word two-part serial, sold it to him somewhere much later in 48 and it appeared first, I think,
in April and May 49. But the research there was entirely biological and not very much was known
about viruses in those days. So as we're in writing a sequel, as I'm supposed to be doing now, I'm
having to do a lot of covering, but I'm damned if I'll tell you where. A contract initially
said manuscript would be turned in September 1976. By September 1976, I had about 7,500 words done
and spills started. I started over again in Christmas vacation and did about 8,500 more words,
starting from scratch once more. Maybe I can use the first 7,500, but I've got a way to go yet.
The contract has been extended to September 77 and I hope I don't have to strengthen for another
extension. We might want their advance back instead. This would be bad.
Well, this happens and some people can get away with it. I lack the
drawl or self-confidence, whichever you want to call it, to feel sure that I'm one of them.
I have told my wife if she wants to go to her sisters in the Bahamas for spring vacation,
she may go and take our daughter with her. I'm not going. I'm staying home with the typewriter.
Whether two and a half weeks spring vacation will really produce the rest of the book is a
wide open question. But at least I keep getting more ideas and writing them down so maybe something
can happen this spring. I hope so. I'd like to get it off my conscience so I can feel I can do
something else. Yes.
Never. When I've written the, they typed out the final draft. What I told myself firmly is the
final draft. I can just barely bring myself to read it. There's some sort of acute postpartum
depression there. And when it comes out as a book, I feel even worse. I know there are things I
should have done otherwise. Take several years, usually before I can read the book of any sort of
comfort.
Yes. We've got a question here. Well, that's it. That's it. What time is it anyway? Okay.
